resources.string: A device reboot is required for Shizuku to work properly. To continue, please reboot your device.
Another version of this app is installed on your device. To continue, please uninstall all duplicate versions and reboot your device.
Battery optimizations must be disabled for start on boot and/or watchdog to work properly.
Start again to update to version %1$s
Please disable \"%1$s\" in Developer Options. You may need to restart the service.
If it\'s stuck searching, try toggling wireless debugging off/on again.
Please go through the pairing step first.
Can\'t connect to wireless debugging service.\n\nPlease ensure that Shizuku is whitelisted in all firewall, ad-block, VPN, or similar apps that can restrict network access.
Wireless debugging is not enabled.\nNote, before Android 11, to enable wireless debugging, computer connection is a must.
USB debugging is not enabled.\nPlease enable it in \"Developer Options\".
Root permission is not granted, or this device is not rooted.
Shizuku is already starting in the background
Shizuku needs WRITE_SECURE_SETTINGS to start on boot. Tap to learn how to grant it.
Wireless debugging mode requires you to complete a one-time pairing process.
Shizuku needs permission to show notifications for the pairing process.
If USB debugging is already enabled, Shizuku will open the Wireless Debugging screen directly if supported.
Enable USB debugging and Wireless debugging in Developer Options.
Select the Wireless debugging row (not just the toggle), then select \"Pair device with pairing code.\"
Enter the code in the pairing notification.
Shizuku will automatically detect the pairing code.
To enter the pairing code, MIUI users may need to switch the notification style to \"Android\" in system settings under Notifications > Notification Shade.
If the pairing fails, please disable battery optimizations and try again.
This service is only supported on TV devices

Provides pairing support for devices (e.g., TVs running Android 14+) where notifications or split screen cannot be used.\n\nEnables Shizuku to extract the pairing code from the wireless debugging pairing screen. It will disable itself once the pairing code is found.

The accessibility service is required to pair with this device. Please enable it to start the pairing process.\n\nIt will automatically disable itself when the code is found or after 1 minute to save energy.

On Android 14, installing/updating Shizuku with the Package Installer revokes the ^1 permission, which is required to enable the accessibility service for pairing.

To grant it, run the following ADB command:

^2

After running the command, you may continue with the pairing process.

Note: you can bypass this by installing/updating Shizuku with ADB.
The system requires the pairing dialog to always be visible. Using split-screen mode is the only way to let this app and the system dialog be visible at the same time.
Unable to generate key for wireless debugging.
Shizuku can change its package name to hide itself from other apps.\n\nNote: some apps may still detect Shizuku even when hidden.
Some apps that use Shizuku may not work with stealth mode because they try to detect if Shizuku is installed.
As a workaround, you can temporarily unhide Shizuku, which installs a stub app with the original package name. When you are finished, you can re-hide Shizuku.
You will need to re-configure Shizuku after installing the stealth version.
This includes: re-pairing wireless debugging, changing settings, re-exporting terminal app files, and updating intents.
You MUST use the in-app updater when using stealth mode.
If left empty, a random suffix will be added to the package name.
Package name cannot end with a period.
Only letters, numbers, and periods are allowed.
Package name must have at least two segments.
Segments cannot start with a number.
Choose a folder where the new APK will be saved.
The system will now prompt you to uninstall Shizuku. Then, install the clone.
Start Shizuku to view authorized apps
Apps that have requested or declared the Shizuku permission will show here.
Terminal apps can run privileged shell commands using Shizuku.
MIUI may break the Storage Access Framework, which the export button uses.
You may have to extract the file from the assets folder in Shizuku\'s APK instead.
Export %1$s and %2$s to a new folder.
Use your terminal app to copy the files to its private files directory.

Tip: If your terminal app\'s home directory is in the private files directory, place the files there to run %1$s without specifying a path.\n\nOtherwise, you can add an alias for %2$s in your terminal\'s %3$s configuration file.
Open a shell with the following command:
Automation apps (e.g., Tasker, MacroDroid) can send intents to start/stop Shizuku automatically.
To use the start intent on your device, you first need to enable ADB over TCP by running %1$s from a PC.
You will need to reconfigure your intents with the new token.
Add the “auth” extra to your intent. You can find your token under “Intents” in the app.
Make sure the token in your intent matches the one shown under “Intents” in the app.
The latest version is already installed
Please disable battery optimization to use this feature.

Due to a bug in Android 11-12, wireless debugging does not remember any authorized networks.\n\nYou will need to re-authorize the network on each reboot by tapping \"Allow\" when the authorization dialog pops up.
Disable USB debugging when stopping Shizuku. It will be re-enabled when Shizuku starts again.
Requires a Wi-Fi connection. With TCP mode, Wi-Fi is only needed once per reboot.
Command must be run after each reboot
Automatically restart Shizuku if it crashes
Watchdog restarted the service. Tap to learn about potential fixes to prevent future crashes.
When enabled, Wi-Fi is only needed to start Shizuku once per reboot
You will need Wi-Fi to turn on TCP mode again.
The service must be restarted to apply this setting.
Shizuku will keep running and wait for a Wi-Fi connection before restarting in the background.
Enter the pairing code in a dialog instead of a notification
Check that you are using the ^1.
Read the ^1 and follow all relevant troubleshooting steps.
Search through all ^1 to see if your bug has already been reported.
Please submit an issue on ^1 if you have an account.
Otherwise, you can send an email.
Allow the app to use Shizuku.
